p: We conventionally represent a sexual contact network with a graph whose nodes, also called vertices, correspond to individuals, and edges, to a sexual association between them. Connected nodes are called neighbours. The number of neighbours for a given node is called its degree, and the degree distribution is one of the defining features of contact network graphs. The sexual contact network therefore maps potential transmission paths for sexually-transmitted pathogens. A graph may also be characterized by community structure, that is, it may contain distinctive, non-overlapping sets of nodes within which we observe a high connection density [ 3]. We call these sets communities.
